Award.AwardTitle: ITR: Collaborative Research: Large Scale Collaboration in Critical Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Organizations operating in critical environments, such as hospitals and security agencies, have evolved into team-based, quasi-decentralized structures. Safety, efficiency, and quality performance in these organizations depend on the ability of the organization to support large scale collaboration-real time coordination across teams, tasks, and resources in a dynamic and risk-prone environment. This research begins to tackle problems of coordination in large-scale collaboration through field research in a trauma center, technology development of mobile devices for real time coordination, and laboratory studies to understand coordination across teams, people, and resources. The research aims to develop a theory of trajectory management and management tools in large-scale collaboration and practical solutions to cross-team coordination. Researchers from University of Maryland Medical School, Carnegie Mellon University, and University of Arizona will collaborate on this research. This project will improve theory in organization science, increase understanding of how to exploit new information technology in critical environments, and improve coordination in hospitals and other vital organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The researchers have examined the detailed requirements of collaboration in medical, business, scientific, and disaster settings. Findings and new technologies for improving collaboration in fast-paced settings have been tested experimentally. In hospitals and other critical settings, we found workarounds to reflect people’s attempts to fix gaps in availability of people, such as nurses, or resources such as operating room equipment. Workarounds have a trickle-down effect, in that one workaround leads to others, thereby increasing the number of people whose work is affected. A systematic analysis of coordination critical incidents identified surprises leading to lack of awareness across groups, bottlenecks due to lack of information synthesis across groups, and conflict due to competition and inconsistent incentive structures. These problems highlight the need for new tools that provide trajectory awareness to hospital personnel. Scheduling surgeries in hospitals is also one of the most challenging activities for surgical staff. Schedule changes occur as often as every few moments, affecting necessary coordination of tasks, resources, and people within and across staff groups, and the stress people feel.  Our research has led to the installation of video feeds in hospital operating rooms so that people working in the area can check on the progress of a surgery and recalibrate their own work or acquire resources in advance. We have developed a set of architectural guidelines for better visibility and coordination in hospitals (see Figure 1). This work is being disseminated to information technologists at the new International Medical Informatics meetings.

Our studies of professional, technical service, and scientific organizations shows that many organizations have much increased their emphasis on teams and their geographic dispersion. The use of new telecommunications technology has made distributed work more feasible but dispersed work arrangements increase the coordination costs of projects and reduce the likelihood of integration of the work (see Figure 2). Managers and workers would rather work locally because dispersed collaborations involve difficulties such as lack of situation awareness and delays in addressing people problems, different incentives across sites, difficulty in seeing how decisions were made and how they change, and bottlenecks in the workflow due to time zone and other problems. We have tested some solutions improving work across sites (for example, using visualizations to improve decision making) and these advances are helpful but do not fully address the problems. 

We have also studied the organization of online help after the Katrina disaster, and our researchers have contributed to new ways of thinking about the role of citizens in disaster work and the opportunistic way that groups work across boundaries during a crisis. Online communities respond to a disaster, for example, by facilitating the distribution of donated goods from ordinary people directly to survivors. These volunteer groups face several challenges—establishing authority within the group, providing relevant information, developing trust in one another, and sustaining the group over time.  Smaller communities seem to do better initially. Decentralized large forum communities had greater difficulties focusing the community’s communication and developing trust but sustained themselves over a long period of time.

This project also has examined cross-cultural communication which is an element of both distributed work arrangement and collaboration in disasters.  The overall goal of this work is to understand ways in which people’s management of multiple trajectories, some of which may be cross-cultural, are affected by their own and their partners’ cultural backgrounds.
